sections.title: Minimizing Investment Taxes
sections.subtitle: Strategies to keep more of your investment returns

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: Tax implications of different investment accounts

sections.title: Account Type Tax Treatment
sections.content: Different accounts have different tax treatments: taxable brokerage accounts, tax-deferred retirement accounts (Traditional IRA/401(k)), and tax-free accounts (Roth IRA/401(k), HSA). Understanding these differences helps you optimize your after-tax returns.

points.title: Taxable Accounts
points.description: Hold tax-efficient investments like index funds and municipal bonds.

points.title: Tax-Deferred Accounts
points.description: Hold investments that generate ordinary income like bonds and REITs.

points.title: Tax-Free Accounts
points.description: Hold growth investments that benefit from tax-free compounding.

sections.title: Asset Location Matters
sections.content: Not all assets are taxed equally. Place tax-inefficient investments (bonds, REITs) in tax-advantaged accounts and tax-efficient investments (stocks) in taxable accounts.

sections.title: Tax-Loss Harvesting
sections.content: This strategy involves selling losing investments to offset gains elsewhere, reducing your tax liability. You can immediately repurchase similar (but not identical) investments to maintain your portfolio allocation while capturing the tax benefit.

sections.title: Optimize Your Tax Efficiency
steps: Review your current asset location across different account types
Move tax-inefficient investments to tax-advantaged accounts
Implement tax-loss harvesting during market downturns
Plan retirement account withdrawals to minimize taxes

sections.title: Consider Tax Diversification
sections.content: Having money in taxable, tax-deferred, and tax-free accounts gives you flexibility in retirement to manage your tax bracket and respond to tax law changes.
